comments.commentBody:
The laws Uber is trying to circumvent are nonsense; they remind me of Anti-miscegenation laws or blue laws or segregation laws--they have a feel to me of "bad-old-days" and are entirely a protection of special interests at the expense of the customer--their removal feels like inevitable progress at last. I especially dislike the disingenuous arguments that the laws are somehow to protect the customer or in any way in the customers' interests when in fact they are specifically trying to benefit taxi monopolies at the customers' expense. Such a lie.
I admit Uber's methods feel a bit more Malcom X than Martin Luther King, but still, I view them as agitators for positive change against unjust laws. If you don't like Uber's service, don't install the app; no one''s making you. If you don't like them as employers, don't work for them, no one's making you.
Exactly.  I don't know why all the busy bodies feel the need to meddle!

How about reading some history books and find out what Malcolm X and Martin Luther King stood for?

Can you imagine that that sleazy UBER CEO would put his life on the line to overcome Jim Crow's laws that made it impossible for black folks to register to vote?

Your comparison sickens me.

You're to one standing against progress in the form of living wages and security. Actually you're pretty shortsighted. People who don't have a living wage, do not patronize stores, and so many doesn't circulate. A recipe for not just another Great Recession but another Great Depression.

Do now use altruistic heroes to justify the reign of selfishness and shortsightedness that you're confusing with technological progress.
Joey, that makes no sense.  Buildings aren't portable.  I think the inspectors will know where to look for them.

Flew to Ft Lauderdale a few weeks ago. Took a regulated taxi to Miami Beach.  Cab beat up and dirty, a sullen driver who drove a hair-raising 90 mph at times even after we objected, and it cost $85.  On the way back a few days later I used Uber.  Clean car, friendly driver who served us water bottles, charged our phones and chatted about the sites, his family, and his appreciation for Uber and the people he gets to meet.  The fare: $38.

Credit Card numbers have meaning.  Judging by the intelligence described in the article the investigators were probably booking with their government credit card accounts which would have been easily detected and probably started with the first 10 numbers all being the same within a single municipality. And data analysis is legally confined, until you expressly give them permission to do whatever they want with your data in the terms and conditions message that nobody ever reads before tapping I Agree.  And if you don't agree you can't use the app.

sure...the good old days of making a decent living driving a cab are gone...
Today the "Ubers" in big cities are owned by capitalists who treat their drivers, the majority of whom are Third World immigrants, miserably. To add insult to economic injury, the "Uber" companies have paid off the politicians to flood the market with "drivers" earning "wages" at levels that were appropriate for the 1970s. At least the "cab companies", with all their flaws, were not destroyed for one big new monopoly: "Uber".

I wish I could delete Uber again. And again.  And again.  Once a week, in fact, to respond to the constant stream of hideous stories produced by this immature, callous spawn of Silicon Valley's sell-out culture.

@Unpresidented
"Drivers may TELL you they love it. Few do. I was one."

What other unskilled job enables workers to start to work whenever they want, to stop work whenever they want, to take a break whenever they want, to work how many hours they want?

Every single driver (and they number in the dozens) that I talked to, raved about the flexibility. Sure, they wished they made more money, but all workers wish the same thing.

Did you ever forget anything in a taxi and try to get it back? Do you know how easy it is with Uber? The driver's contact is right there on your phone.

Do you enjoy having to reach out for cash (or a credit card when they accept it) at the end of a trip to pay for a taxi? Do you know how good it feels to just open the door of the Uber car and go when you arrive, with the receipt arriving neatly in your mailbox and sent directly to your company's expense reporting system?

I could go on and on and on.

Taxi service, even in the best of places (like NYC), is hopelessly archaic, inconvenient, with artificially suppressed demand (medallions and the like). Users deserve better, and Uber gives it to them.

Uber was a tiny company taking on corrupt municipal and international governments, suffering violence to be able to operate.

Good for them that they developed smart countermeasures. Bravo.
Uber has a $1 Mln per accident liability policy that is in force when passenger is in the car.
I'm more interested in police enforcing texting and driving laws than protecting the taxi industry.

In Michigan there was one uber driver that went on a mass murder sniper rampage and one that stabbed a customer in the highest end city in the state.  By not following regulations, uber is not a responsible employer, nor service provider.  In addition they pay no taxes for the use of infrastructure they rely on. It is electronic hitch hiking , which illegal almost everywhere.
No surprise here, another sleazy, dishonest, narcissistic, law dodging silicon valley company.
The times dropped in the word "workplace" to boost their false claim that Uber drivers are employees.
Why in the world do some people feel the need to get in the way of a willing driver and a willing customer?
The cases are different because in the Uber case no one is harmed by the customer's using the product (except the competitor offering the same service - but then what's capitalism?)

@John, Why in the world would you equate someone who needs a ride with someone who is compelled to seek out addictive substances that will maim or kill them?

I don't have any idea what Uber in Utah is like, but before Uber, the laws in Utah for Taxi services were so strict, about the only way you could get a taxi was to get to or from the airport.

Why in the world to governments think that restricting such services is beneficial for those who need rides?

Wow, that was pretty lame analogy.  An addict is under the influence when he buys a drug, which prevents him from making a free choice.  This is hardly true for rider.  An addict is killing himself by doing drugs, whereas a rider is getting a valuable service.  By your logic, government could interfere int he free exchange of goods and services between any individual by claiming it's ok to prevent a drug addict from buying a drug.
No, they are making profits. Which are proof of creating great value for their customers, who are ordinary people, by the way.
Yes Richard, exactly the way the Republicans put aside the desperate bushwacking of the legitimately elected President Obama.

He knows everything. He chose these liars on purpose. He needs unethical people around him to make sure he can do what he wants. Anyone who is honest will jump overboard quickly, once they see the corrupting rot at the dark heart of this nightmare, or they'll be fired once he figures out that they're more loyal to truth than to his ego. Only a matter of time.
So what if Obama's most loyal campaign advisers and the Attorney General were consorting with an American enemy?

This lady and others in this so called world's most popular newspaper just want to make this administration not to execute anything as the executive branch of the government of this nation.

You should focus on actions and not on talks. This county now has the most transparent executive branch in the world thanks to many chatters even in the most secretive parts of it. And you are the biggest mouth in the world with largest ears. So, you can do your job of checking this government for the public very successfully by focusing only on executive actions. Please, please do that, not what you have been doing for so long. It's way too much and I am fed up.

One more request to you is to criticize yourself who divide the 99% into poor white males and the rest of them. You blame the poor white males as deplorable racist bigots by eliciting small outliers in them, while you blame others who call extreme terrorists as Muslim terrorists even if there are so many such terrorists all over the world and all of them are sincere and proud Muslims. Please apologize to the innocent people you blamed.

"...want to make this administration not to execute anything as the executive branch of the government of this nation."

Sounds suspiciously like something Mitch McConnell and his Russophile henchmen said and did for the EIGHT YEARS of the Obama presidency. So please, stop with the crocodile tears and understand that the Republicans' chickens are coming home to roost in the very swamp they created. You'll get neither sympathy nor kid glove treatment from me.

Why the need for euphemism about Session's lies?  He didn't "misspeak."  He didn't give "erroneous" testimony.  It would be "erroneous" if he made an unintentional mistake answering the question from Franken, but that's not what happened here.  No, he simply, flat-out, lied.  And now he's making up embarrassingly lame justifications as to why he didn't feel he needed to answer the question.  Maybe it's time for The Times and other publications to calmly and respectfully just call a lie a lie.  These people need to be called out, not given the cover of euphemism.

It seems obvious that Sessions will have to go at some point. He has been asked to reappear at the Judiciary committee to clear up his testimony and he has agreed to respond to written questions with written answers on Monday. Don't think that will fly for long. Chairman Grassley is a Grand Old Pirate to be sure but I don't think he can withstand the pressure to have Sessions testify again in person, under oath, at which time I would expect that Sessions would hoist himself on his own Petard if his inept news conference today is anything to go by.

All of this is subject to change overnight as we seem to get more information damning this new administration almost hourly. It is so surreal now that you get the feeling at times that you are reading a trashy novel.

My vote is obvious. Sessions has to go. Next week perhaps. In the meantime. Resist.
Actually, the most pitiful thing is that Trump probably couldn’t even read this off a teleprompter.  And it doesn’t fit in a tweet.

I think we need to have a congressional investigation, on the behalf of the American people, on the Democrat who has uttered these words Ms. Collins quotes: “He has these horrible views, but he’s sort of not vicious about them.”

He may not be personally vicious about them but he will turn them these horrible views into policy and the policies will certainly be vicious towards African-Americans and other people not favored by the Republican party (just draw up a list of those who they try to exclude from voting).

I cannot believe a true Democrat would actually speak those words.

Yes indeed. It is all so outrageous and farcical, and done so openly and with such straight faces.
How did we, our society, our country, get to this point?
Will Americans have more or less faith in their government as a result of this?

America does appear to have an affinity for cult figures and crackpots, dangerous ones too, and I remember when Ms. Collins covered the news of a preacher who wanted to burn copies of the Koran. A friend and me happened to be working together at the time in the water department of an international agency for children, and we both shook our heads, while I snorted. She is a devout Muslim and I am somewhere in the clouds. Beam me, up!

Why worry about Jeff Sessions? Trump apparently does not worry about anything, according to a reporter last year, as El Commandante plunged his fork into a thick slice of velveteen cake on a plane interview and way to go! I rather like that motto when all is said and done, except that it does make one uneasy to see America go down the pipes, O Danny Boy, you have done us wrong.

If Trump can say, licking his chops, that he can shoot up Fifth Avenue and walk free, well I guess he can be chums with Russia too. Then we have Prince Machiavelli on site, making Iago sound like a weakling, Mr. Bannon is having tons of fun at our expense, it's really quite a Party.

Unfortunately, we have to take it seriously. Normally we wouldn't even be having this exchange. Oh, no, and then there are the grousers among us who were worried about having the same old, same old. Well, tears are often shed over answered prayers, and Sessions is here to stay.
The circle of treason tightens like a noose around this fake presidency.
